video.title: Tormented Souls and The Artful Escape (Zero Punctuation)

captions.text:
Well I guess the release drought&#39;s officially 
over, we&#39;ve had so many review codes come into

Escapist Towers we&#39;ve had to sell some of them 
off as gently used wi-fi passwords. I played the

first hour of like nine different games this 
week, it&#39;s been like speed dating but where

you get to piss on their face. Can&#39;t cover them 
all but gratifyingly I can selectively highlight

the ones that actually stirred something in me, 
whether that be admiration or a second round of

contemptful wee wee. Starting with Tormented 
Souls, which as you might have guessed from

the title is without hyperbole the most generic 
survival horror game in the universe. If this

were 1999, that is, because Fermented Balls is 
deliberately aping old PS1 era Resident Evil Alone

in the Dark fixed camera games and if you&#39;ve only 
played modern horror games where you walk through

a funhouse hall of mirrors for two hours then 
get a participation award then you&#39;re going to

fucking hate it. &quot;Why can&#39;t I angle the camera to 
look at the thing that&#39;s about to twat me across

the room?&quot; Because it&#39;s a deliberate homage to 
retro fixed camera horror games! &quot;Why does the

camera angle keep suddenly reversing and making 
me spin on my heel and sprint right back into the

monster I&#39;m trying to flee like a nervous deer at 
a busy junction?&quot; Deliberate homage retro horror!

&quot;Why can&#39;t I save whenever I want? What if my 
pet chinchilla suddenly goes into labour?&quot; Don&#39;t

blame me, blame deliberate homage! I ragequit 
after my first attempt because I used the first

save game token I found way too early and kept 
getting killed because combat&#39;s like trying to

disentangle two dog leashes with both your hands 
trapped in Pringles tubes DELIBERATE HOMAGE Oh

piss off. But I started again and powered through 
and by the end of the game I had enough ammo to

make combat trivial and I was having to sell off 
unused save tokens as gently used drinks coasters.

Bit of a reverse difficulty curve issue, but I 
have to admit I was somewhat engaged with the

gameplay by then, either out of nostalgia for 
the old Silent Hills or a sheer bloody-minded

unwillingness to go back to playing Lost Judgment. 
It wasn&#39;t the fucking story, which is so achingly

generic it&#39;s like it&#39;s trying to set a record 
for the Guinness Book of Things That Are So Lazy

I Can&#39;t Be Bothered To Finish This Joke Properly. 
Wake up in an abandoned hospital with no memory,

check. Monsters are all abominations of humanity 
who look like they got their brain surgery done

by a forgetful orthodontist, check. Main character 
seems to have the acting range of a wank sock and

gets her tits out in literally her second scene 
of the game - more a movie horror cliche I suppose

but fuck it, pile it on. Also there&#39;s cults and 
really illogical locking mechanisms and I guessed

the secret twist of the main character&#39;s origin 
within the first thirty seconds. It also seems to

be trying to cram in as many stolen ideas from 
its influences as it can - you have to go to a

Silent Hill-esque evil rusty dark world version 
of the hospital on two brief occasions, but it

was evil science experiments horror up to then, 
you can&#39;t just right turn into Hellraiser reality

embuggerance horror and then left turn straight 
back again like a lost dad on a poorly signposted

highway junction. However accurately Torrential 
Spooge recreates retro survival horror and its

classic sense of vulnerability from being obliged 
to fight off demons while having the combat skill

of a man with his elbows glued together, there&#39;s 
something terribly grubby and ramshackle about

it. Between the gratuituous nudity, numerous plot 
holes, and crazy quilt of stolen ideas, it&#39;s like

there&#39;s no higher thinking behind anything in 
it beyond &quot;other horror games have done it&quot; and

&quot;titties are nice.&quot; It also uses its soundtrack 
the way I use urine on a speed date. No silence,

no contemplative moments, just a constant conveyer 
belt of spooky music and low drones like we just

flushed our earbuds down the toilet in Michael 
Myers&#39; house. In brief, Toronto Smells is exactly

what it appears to be on the surface and nothing 
more, which makes for an interesting contrast with

our second game, The Artful Escape. A game that 
after the first ten minutes I really thought I was

going to hate. You&#39;re a young hipster guitarist 
whose glasses are as large as his trousers are

tight living in a small town where everyone 
expects him to live up to his famous guitarist

uncle but he&#39;s sad because he wants to have his 
own identity, and instantly I assumed we were in

Dreamscaper slash Sea of Solitude territory - the 
&quot;get the fuck over yourself&quot; hipster indie game

about a boo hoo this small town is oppressing my 
creative free spirit why doesn&#39;t anyone understand

my privileged conventionally attractive person 
problems conventionally attractive person who

will probably end up moving to New York and 
then never leaving their apartment because

they&#39;re afraid of all the shouty people.
Indie games are supposed to be a place

of unbridled creativity unyoked from publisher 
interference so why do people keep making games

about sad people in apartments? Also, it uses 
split pin paper cutout character animation like

what I griped about in my Ender Lilies review, the 
IKEA flatpack of animation styles where characters

stand stiffly around like wet floor signs with 
poor posture, and has some big name voice actors

like Carl Weathers, and I railed against big 
name actors in games in my 12 Minutes review,

speaking of sad people in apartments. So I was 
settling in to massage the hate boner on this

one. But then, a few hours later, my dude was on 
a neon stage the size of the greater London area,

dressed like a cross between the Goblin King and 
Geordi Laforge, playing a cosmic glam rock solo

for the benefit of a gigantic transcendental 
space moth while the universe exploded in the

background. Yeah, it takes a bit of a turn. 
After the initial humdrum beginning there&#39;s

a point when the game suddenly bursts into this 
psychedelic voyage of music and visuals like 2001:

A Space Odyssey by way of Yellow Submarine. 
Yes, it&#39;s an intergalactic ego trip revolving

around a whiny twerp and his pedestrian guitar 
solos, but it&#39;s stylish enough I didn&#39;t care.

Cruddy Holly and his stiff-ass paper cutout 
animation shrinks to a tiny pinprick against

these vast, animated prog rock album covers and it 
sucked me in, I played through it in one session

and came away poised to recommend. If it weren&#39;t 
for one thing. No, it didn&#39;t turn out to be all a

dream. It did fucking seem like it might and that 
certainly would have scythed the glittery platform

shoes out from under the plot, but thankfully 
it didn&#39;t. The problem with Artful Escape is,

and you&#39;re breaking my fucking heart here, 
guys - it forgot to have any fucking gameplay.

It&#39;s a glorified 2D walking sim, I spent the whole 
time hoping to God it would finally introduce a

mechanic beyond pressing right, occasionally 
pausing to fight a monster by waiting for it

to play a note and then playing the same note 
straight back. In context this is supposed to

be us demonstrating our legendary guitar prowess 
that makes suns go supernova and every barren

female in the star system simultaneously emit 
two pints of hot climax juice, and any amount

of skill challenge beyond just playing Simon for 
five minutes could have really emphasised that.

I guess I still recommend for the sheer spectacle, 
but ultimately it&#39;s like going on It&#39;s A Small

World: you spend the whole time on a conveyer 
belt wishing you could kick someone&#39;s teeth in.
